name: London
intro_vibe: The City of Villages: Royal heritage meets modern multicultural energy in a sprawling, polycentric capital.

general_info.description: London is the capital and largest city of England and the United Kingdom. As one of the world's most influential cities, London has been a major settlement for two millennia. It is a leading global city in arts, commerce, education, entertainment, fashion, finance, healthcare, media, professional services, research and development, tourism, and transportation. But beyond the monuments, it operates as a federation of distinct 'villages'—from the polished streets of Marylebone to the gritty creativity of Shoreditch—fused by history and the Tube.

weather_breakdown.name: January
weather_breakdown.clothing: Warm coat, waterproof layers, sturdy boots

weather_breakdown.name: June
weather_breakdown.clothing: Summer clothes + light jacket for evenings

weather_breakdown.name: December
weather_breakdown.clothing: Heavy winter coat, gloves, warm hat

etiquette_tips: Tube Silence: On the Underground, silence is golden. Do not talk loudly, play music, or make prolonged eye contact. It is a private space in public.
Escalator Discipline: Stand on the RIGHT, walk on the LEFT. Blocking the left side is the fastest way to annoy a Londoner. This rule is absolute.
Queueing is Sacred: Never cut in line. The queue is a British institution and jumping it is social suicide. If unsure, ask 'Who is last?'.
The Round System: If you are with a group in a pub, you buy in 'rounds' (one person buys for everyone). Do not buy just for yourself. Reciprocate before leaving.
The Nuance of 'Sorry': Londoners say 'Sorry' for everything—bumping into you, you bumping into them, or just existing. It is a reflex to diffuse tension, not an admission of guilt.
Cashless Society: Buses do not accept cash. Most coffee shops and bars are 'Card Only'. You tap for everything. Bring a contactless card/phone.
Pub Service: Order at the bar. There is rarely table service for drinks. Say 'and one for yourself' to offer the bartender a tip (usually taken as ~£1).
Tipping: 10-12.5% is usually added as a 'Service Charge' to restaurant bills. You do not need to tip on top of this. No tipping expected in pubs.
Mind the Gap: Pay attention to the warning between the train and platform.
Volume: Londoners are quiet on transit. Keep voice volume low.

neighborhoods.name: Westminster & South Bank
neighborhoods.description: Home to Big Ben, Parliament, the London Eye, and the Thames riverside walk. Touristy but unmissable for first-timers.

neighborhoods.name: Shoreditch & Brick Lane
neighborhoods.description: Street art, vintage markets, curry houses, and nightlife. The edgy, creative heart of East London. Home to the famous Sunday markets.

neighborhoods.name: Marylebone
neighborhoods.description: The polished, affluent 'village' in the center of the city. Marylebone High Street offers the perfect balance of boutiques, cheese shops, and cafes without the crushing crowds of Oxford Street nearby.

neighborhoods.name: Notting Hill & Portobello
neighborhoods.description: Pastel townhouses, antique markets, and upscale bohemian vibes. Made famous by the Hugh Grant film.

neighborhoods.name: Hampstead
neighborhoods.description: Perched on a hill in North London, it feels like a wealthy country town. Famous for the Heath (wild swimming), historic pubs, and intellectual history (Freud, Keats). A breath of fresh air.

neighborhoods.name: Covent Garden
neighborhoods.description: Street performers, boutique shops, theaters, and restaurants. Always buzzing with energy day and night.

neighborhoods.name: Brixton
neighborhoods.description: The heart of Caribbean culture in London. Vibrant, loud, and community-focused. Famous for the Electric Avenue market, music venues (Academy), and incredible food culture.

neighborhoods.name: Camden Town
neighborhoods.description: Punk heritage, sprawling markets, live music venues, and canal-side street food. Unique London character.

neighborhoods.name: South Kensington
neighborhoods.description: Museum quarter with world-class institutions, elegant Victorian architecture, and upscale dining.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The Tube is your best friend. Get an Oyster Card or use contactless payment.
details: Contactless is King: You do not need an Oyster card anymore. Use your contactless bank card or Apple/Google Pay. It's the same price and caps daily.
The Tube: 11 lines. Avoid peak hours (7:30-9:30am, 5-7pm). It is fast but hot and deep.
The Bus Strategy: Slower but scenic and cheaper (£1.75). Routes 11 and 24 offer a budget sightseeing tour.
Walking: London is walkable. Download CityMapper (better than Google Maps for transit details).
Uber Boat: The 'Thames Clippers' are a valid commuter option. Tapping in guarantees a scenic ride along the river.

logistics.title: Safety: The Phone Snatch
logistics.summary: London is safe, but phone theft is an epidemic.
details: The E-Bike Snatch: Thieves on electric bikes mount the pavement and snatch phones from hands in seconds. It happens in broad daylight.
The Rule: NEVER walk near the curb while using your phone. Step inside a doorway or stand with your back to a wall to check maps.
Hotspots: Oxford Circus, Islington, Shoreditch, and London Bridge are high-risk zones.
Emergency Number: 999 for police/ambulance.

logistics.title: Nightlife & Adult Context
logistics.summary: London has a regulated adult industry in specific zones like Soho.
details: The Reality: Unlike Bangkok, London's 'Red Light' scene is discreet and mostly indoors (gentlemen's clubs).
Key Areas: Soho and parts of Shoreditch. These areas are safe and trendy, but have historic adult venues.
Safety Tip: Avoid street promoters offering 'private shows' or cheap drinks. These are almost always scams.
Behavior: Photography is prohibited in venues. Prices are very high.

logistics.title: Scams to Avoid
logistics.summary: London is safe, but watch for ticket touts and 'games'.
details: Ticket Touts: Never buy theater tickets from street sellers. Use TKTS booth.
The Cup Game: People playing gambling games on Westminster Bridge. It is rigged. You will lose.
Fake Monks: People asking for 'donations' for a plastic bracelet. Politely decline.
The 'Free' Gift: Refuse roses or heather handed to you; they will demand cash.

logistics.title: Survival Tips
details: Water: Tap water is safe and delicious. Ask for 'Tap Water' in restaurants; it's free. Carry a bottle.
Rickshaws: Avoid neon-lit pedicabs in the West End. They are unregulated and charge extortionate prices (£50+).
Thursday is the New Friday: Post-pandemic, Thursday is the big office drinking night. Pubs are packed.

logistics.title: Apps to Download
logistics.summary: These apps will make navigating London much easier.
details: CityMapper: The absolute best for transit navigation.
TfL Go: Official Transport for London app.
Uber / Bolt: Ride-hailing apps.
Trainline: For booking trains to other cities.

must_eat.description: The sacred weekly ritual. Roasted meat (beef, pork, lamb) served with Yorkshire pudding, roast potatoes, veg, and gravy. Served in pubs strictly on Sundays from 12pm until sold out (usually 4pm). Book a table in advance.

The quintessential British dish: battered white fish (cod/haddock) with thick chips and mushy peas. Best from a proper 'chippy' (takeaway shop) wrapped in paper, not a fancy restaurant. Add salt and vinegar.
The legendary breakfast: bacon, sausages, eggs, beans, tomatoes, mushrooms, and toast. The ultimate hangover cure. Find it in a 'Greasy Spoon' cafe for the authentic experience.
London's 'true' national dish. Brick Lane is famous but touristy; try Tayyabs (Whitechapel) or Dishoom for superior quality. Tooting ('Curry Corridor') is the authentic local spot.
Cornerstone of culture. Try a pint of real ale or cider. Order at the bar. 'Gastropubs' serve excellent restaurant-quality food, distinct from 'chain pubs' (Wetherspoons).
The inflation-beater. A sandwich, a snack (crisps/chocolate), and a drink for about £3.50-£4.00 from supermarkets like Tesco or Sainsbury's. The fuel of the office worker.
Modern London eats at markets. Borough Market is the titan (try the chorizo roll or paella), but Maltby Street Market is the cooler, locals-only alternative under the railway arches.
Traditional East End working-class dish: meat pie with mash and green parsley 'liquor'. A taste of old London.
A Brick Lane icon. Hot salt beef with mustard and pickles in a chewy boiled bagel. Open 24/7 at Beigel Bake (the white one).
A core part of London's identity. Jerk chicken, patties, and rice & peas. Authentic spots found in Brixton and Notting Hill.

items.description: The iconic clock tower and seat of government. Best viewed from Westminster Bridge.
Giant Ferris wheel offering panoramic city views. Book online to skip queues. Alternatively, view from Parliament Hill for free.
Most famous bridge in London. Watch the bridge lift times online.
The best free activity. Walk from Westminster to Tower Bridge along the river. Street performers, book markets, and pubs.
A peaceful towpath walk from Little Venice to Camden. Houseboats, cafes, and greenery away from traffic. See the London Zoo for free from the path.
World-class theatre. Get discount same-day tickets at the TKTS booth in Leicester Square.
Stunning Victorian cemetery overgrown with nature. Gothic atmosphere and Karl Marx's grave.
Home to the Rosetta Stone and Elgin Marbles. Dedicated to human history, art, and culture. Free entry.
Contemporary art housed in a colossal former power station. The Turbine Hall installations are world-famous. Free entry.
Dinosaurs and the blue whale in a stunning cathedral-like building. Free entry.
London's premier food market. Go Wed-Sat. It is crowded but smells divine. Great for cheese, bread, and street food.
A neon wonderland in Walthamstow. A niche, Instagrammable warehouse filled with vintage signs and props. Very cool.
1000-year-old fortress housing the Crown Jewels. Former prison and palace. Beefeater tours are essential theater.
The setting for coronations and royal weddings. A stunning gothic masterpiece packed with history.
Iconic dome dominating the skyline. Climb to the top for views.
Wild, rolling hills overlooking the city. A stark contrast to manicured Royal Parks. Swim in the ponds if you dare.

affiliate_products.title: Universal Travel Adapter (UK Type G)
affiliate_products.reason: UK plugs are unique (three rectangular pins). You absolutely need this adapter.

affiliate_products.title: Compact Travel Umbrella
affiliate_products.reason: London weather is famously unpredictable. A small umbrella fits in your bag.

affiliate_products.title: Waterproof Walking Shoes
affiliate_products.reason: London requires a LOT of walking. Comfortable shoes are essential.
